2024  Propositions
==================



The original Charter Commission was appointed on June 26, 1946 and the original Charter was adopted and approved on April 05, 1949.  The Edinburg City Charter has had subsequent amendments on March 03, 1953; October 21, 1969; April 15, 1975; November 17, 1981; March 07, 1989; January 22, 1996; November 16, 2011 and November 20, 2018.

On August 15, 2023, the Edinburg City Council established a Charter Review Committee, charged with reviewing the existing City of Edinburg Charter and making recommendations to the City Council.  There were five members who served on the committee, and each member was appointed by a member of the City Council.  The Charter Review Committee held Bi‐Weekly Meetings from December 01, 2023 to May 23, 2024 to review the Edinburg City Charter.  On June 18, 2024 the Charter Review Committee presented the Proposed Charter Amendments to the Edinburg City Council.  At the July 16, 2024 City Council Regular Meeting the Edinburg City Council held a Public Hearing on the City of Edinburg Charter Propositions.  After said public hearing, Edinburg City Council approved Resolution No. 2639 ordering the City of Edinburg Charter Special Election to be held during the Uniform Election on November 05, 2024.

La Comisión Constitutiva original fue nombrada el 26 de junio de 1946 y la Carta original fue adoptada y aprobada el 5 de abril de 1949. La Carta de la Ciudad de Edinburg ha tenido enmiendas posteriores el 3 de marzo de 1953; 21 de octubre de 1969; 15 de abril de 1975; 17 de noviembre de 1981; 07 de marzo de 1989; 22 de enero de 1996; 16 de noviembre de 2011 y 20 de noviembre de 2018.

El 15 de agosto de 2023, el Concejo Municipal de Edinburg estableció un Comité de Revisión de Estatutos, encargado de revisar los Estatutos existentes de la Ciudad de Edinburg y hacer recomendaciones al Concejo Municipal. Había cinco miembros que servían en el comité, y cada miembro era nombrado por un miembro del Concejo Municipal. El Comité de Revisión de la Carta Constitucional celebró reuniones quincenales desde el 1 de diciembre de 2023 hasta el 23 de mayo de 2024 para revisar la Carta Constitucional de la Ciudad de Edinburg. El 18 de junio de 2024, el Comité de Revisión de la Carta Constitutiva presentó las Enmiendas Propuestas a la Carta al Concejo Municipal de Edinburg. En la Reunión Ordinaria del Concejo Municipal del 16 de julio de 2024, el Concejo Municipal de Edinburg celebró una Audiencia Pública sobre las Proposiciones de la Carta Constitutiva de la Ciudad de Edinburg. Después de dicha audiencia pública, el Concejo Municipal de Edinburg aprobó la Resolución No. 2639 que ordena que la Elección Especial de la Carta Constitutiva de la Ciudad de Edinburg se lleve a cabo durante la Elección Uniforme el 05 de noviembre de 2024.

#### [Charter Amendments With Redlines/Enmiendas a Los Estatutos con Línea Roja](https://cityofedinburg.com/Elections/Charter%20with%20Redlines-Presentation.pdf) [Charter redline / Línea Roja de los Estatutos](https://cityofedinburg.com/Elections/Charter%20Redline-Final%20(2).pdf) [Resolution No. 2639 / Resolución Núm. 2639](https://cityofedinburg.com/Elections/Resolution%20No.%202639.pdf) [October 15, 2024 City Council Regular Meeting Charter Presentation](https://cityofedinburg.com/Elections/Charter%20Election%20Presentation.pptx)

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Agenda** | **Recording** |
| [View Agenda](https://edinburgtx.portal.civicclerk.com/event/82/files/agenda/276) | [View Recording](https://edinburgtx.new.swagit.com/videos/308233) |
| [View Agenda](https://edinburgtx.portal.civicclerk.com/event/66/files) | [View Recording](https://edinburgtx.new.swagit.com/videos/310403) |

[Sample Ballot/Boleta de Muestra](https://cityofedinburg.com/Elections/Sample%20Ballot.pdf)

**Charter Proposition A**

**Should Article II Section 4 be amended to revise the process for filling vacancies on the city council to be consistent with the requirements of the Texas Constitution, which requires that vacancies with more than one year be ordered to a special election?**

The proposed amendment would update the charter on the process for filling vacancies on the city council according to the current laws in the State of Texas

**Charter Proposition B**

**Should Article II Section 3, Article V Section 3, Article VI Section 1, Article VIII Section 2, and Article XVIII Section 1 be amended so that the City’s appointed positions (City Manager, City Attorney, City Secretary, and Municipal Court Clerk) each serve until removed by the City Council?**

The proposed amendment would allow appointed positions to serve at the discretion of the City Council. Currently the terms of the appointed positions are two (2) four-year terms.

**Charter Proposition C**

**Should Article III Section 9 be amended to require that the City’s ordinances and notices be published in accordance with state law?**

The proposed amendment would allow publications of all ordinances, notices and other matters as required by the charter or by the ordinances to be published according to the current laws in the State of Texas.  Currently the Charter states the City Council shall enter into a contract with a newspaper as the official paper continuing as such until another is selected.

**Charter Proposition D**

**Should Article III Section 1 and Section 2 be amended to clarify that newly elected City Council Members and the Mayor take office at the regular City Council meeting following an election and that a Mayor Pro Tem be chosen by the City Council at that meeting?**

The proposed amendment would update the Charter so that immediately following the election and qualification of new members, or as soon after such election and qualification as practicable, the city council shall meet at the usual place for holding its meetings and the newly elected members shall assume the duties of office. It would also update the charter so that at the first meeting of the city council immediately following the election and qualification of new members or as soon thereafter as practicable, the city council shall choose one of the council members as mayor pro tem.  This section currently states newly elected members shall assume office on the second Tuesday of May following a regular municipal election.

**Charter Proposition E**

**Should Article IV Section 4 be amended to conform the city’s posting of the names of candidates in a city election with the requirements of state law?**

The proposed amendment would update the City of Edinburg Charter with the current laws in the State of Texas. The city secretary shall, for each city election post in accordance with the requirements of state law a list of the names of all candidates who have filed their own petitions or who have been nominated by petitions for the offices to be voted on at such election.

**Charter Proposition F**

**Should Article II Section 2 and Article IV Section 5-A be amended to conform city elections to Texas Constitution requirements that candidates for an elective office must receive a majority of all votes cast rather than a plurality?**

The proposed amendment would update the City of Edinburg Charter with the current laws in the State of Texas that an elective office must receive a majority of all votes. Currently Article II Section 2 of the charter states that candidate receiving a plurality of votes in each place shall be considered elected for such term and position and Article IV Section 5-A states that the candidates receiving a plurality of the votes for said respective office shall be declared elected.

**Charter Proposition G**

**Should Article VI Section 1 be amended to require that the City Attorney be a full-time city employee?**

The proposed amendment would allow for the City Attorney to be a full time city employee subject to the same employment policies, benefits and working conditions as other city administrative employees.  The City Attorney shall report to the City Council.  Currently the City Attorney is not required to be a full time city employee.

**Charter Proposition H**

**Should Article VII Section 1, Section 3, and Section 4 be amended to clarify that the City’s Finance Director is the head of the City’s department of finance (rather than the City Manager) and that the Finance Director reports to the City Manager?**

The proposed amendment would update the Charter stating that the director of the Department of Finance to head the Finance Department and report to the City Manager.  Currently the charter states the director of the department of finance is the City Manager.

**Charter Proposition I**

**Should Article VIII Section 1 be amended to require that the Municipal Court Judge be an attorney who has practiced in the State of Texas for at least three (3) years and otherwise clarify that the municipal court has the jurisdiction provided by and should be conducted in accordance with state law?**

The proposed amendment would update the Charter stating that the Municipal Court Judge to be an attorney who has practiced in the State of Texas for at least three (3) years and otherwise clarifies that the municipal court has the jurisdiction provided by and should be conducted in accordance with state law.    Currently the charter states that the municipal court judge shall possess the same qualifications of office as providing in the charter for the mayor and council members.

**Charter Proposition J**

**Should the City Charter be amended by revising various sections of Articles XII - XVI to clarify the procedures for petitioning a recall, initiative, or referendum election including requiring that all petitions be signed by a certain number of qualified voters of the city; making clear that the powers of initiative and referendum do not extend to ordinances relating to bonds, the city’s finances and budgeting, or causing the city to spend money; removing the requirement that petitions be circulated only by a committee of circulators; and establishing that signatures to a petition remain effective for 30 days prior to the filing of the petition with the city?**

The proposed amendment would require the recall petition be signed by qualified voters of the city equal in number to at least twenty-five percent of the number of votes cast in the preceding regular municipal election. Article XIII Section 1 of the charter currently states the recall petition to be effective must be returned and filed with the city secretary within thirty (30) days after the filing of the affidavit, and it must bear the signature of the voters of the city to the number of at least twenty-five (25) percent number of voters who cast their votes at last preceding regular municipal election; provided, however, that the petition shall not be effective unless it bears the signature of at least three hundred (300) voters of the city.

The proposed amendment would include the following: The voters shall have power to propose any ordinance, with the exception of ordinances levying taxes; ordinances relating to the issuance, sale and delivery of bonds;  ordinances relating to the city’s finances and budgeting; and ordinances causing the city (directly or indirectly) to appropriate or spend money and to adopt or  reject the same at the polls, such power being known as the initiative. Any initiated ordinance may be submitted to the city council by petition signed by qualified votes of the city equal in number to at least twenty-five (25) percent of the number of votes cast in the preceding regular municipal election provided however that the petition must beat the signatures of at least three hundred (300) voters of the city.  Article XIV. Section 1 of the charter currently states any ordinance except an appropriation ordinance or an ordinance making a tax levy; signed by voters of the city equal in number to at least ten (10) percent of those who voted at the last regular municipal election; must bear the signatures of at least one hundred (100) voters.

The proposed amendment would add the exception of ordinances levying taxes; ordinances relating to the issuance, sale, and delivery of bonds; ordinances relating to the city’s finances and budgeting; and ordinances causing the city (directly or indirectly) to appropriate or spend money.  Article XV Section 1 currently states the voters shall have power to approve or reject at the polls any ordinance passed by the city council, or submitted by the city council to a vote of the voters, except an appropriation ordinance or an ordinance making the annual tax levy

The proposed amendment changes the qualified voters from 20 to 25 percent and from two hundred to three hundred voters.  Article XV Section 2 currently states within not more than thirty (30) days after the final passage by the city council of any ordinance which is subject to referendum, a petition signed by qualified voters of the city equal in number to at least twenty (20) percent of those who voted in the last preceding regular municipal election, and in no case less than two hundred voters

The proposed amendment to Article XVI Section 1 adds that no signatures to a petition shall remain effective or be counted which were placed thereon more than thirty (30) days prior to the filing of such petition or petitions with the city pursuant to this Charter and removes that there shall appear on each petition the names and addresses of five (5) voters of the city, and on each paper the names and addresses of the same five (5) voters, who, as a committee of the petitioner, shall be regarded as responsible for the circulation and filing of the petition, but such five (5) voters shall only be counted one time in the total voters signing the petition.

**Charter Proposition K**

**Should Article XVII Section 11 be amended to require that the city appoint a charter review committee to review the City Charter and recommend amendments, if any, every five years during years ending in 0 or 5?**

The proposed amendment would amend the Charter by adding that the City Council shall appoint a charter review committee, consisting of at least five members, each year ending in 0 or 5 (except for the year 2025) . The charter review committee shall review the City Charter and recommend amendments, if any, to the City Council.  Currently there is no section in the charter for a charter review committee.
